topics.title: Introduction to Projectile Motion
key_concepts: Projectile motion is motion of an object under gravity after an initial launch, neglecting air resistance.
Horizontal and vertical motions are independent: horizontal velocity is constant; vertical motion has constant acceleration g downward.
The trajectory of an ideal projectile on level ground is a parabola.

important_terms.definition: Any object that, after an initial impulse, moves under the influence of gravity alone (neglecting air resistance).
The path followed by a projectile; for ideal projectiles this is a parabola.
Angle between the initial velocity vector and the horizontal axis.
Horizontal distance traveled by the projectile between launch and landing (on the same vertical level).

topics.summary: Projectile motion combines constant horizontal velocity with uniformly accelerated vertical motion due to gravity, producing a parabolic trajectory when air resistance is neglected.

topics.title: Kinematic Equations and Component Analysis
key_concepts: Decompose initial velocity v0 into horizontal (v0x = v0 cosθ) and vertical (v0y = v0 sinθ) components.
Horizontal motion: x(t) = v0x * t (no horizontal acceleration).
Vertical motion: y(t) = y0 + v0y * t - (1/2) g t^2 and vy(t) = v0y - g t.

important_terms.definition: v0x = v0 cosθ and v0y = v0 sinθ; used to analyze motion in x and y separately.
Downward acceleration, commonly g = 9.81 m/s^2 near Earth's surface.
For launches and landings at same height, time to rise equals time to fall; vertical speed magnitudes at equal heights are equal and opposite.

topics.summary: Solve projectile problems by splitting motion into perpendicular x and y components, apply constant-velocity kinematics in x and constant-acceleration kinematics in y, then recombine results.

topics.title: Range, Time of Flight, and Maximum Height
key_concepts: Time of flight for level ground: T = (2 v0 sinθ) / g.
Maximum height: H = (v0^2 sin^2 θ) / (2 g).
Range on level ground: R = (v0^2 sin 2θ) / g; maximum range occurs at θ = 45°.

important_terms.definition: Total time the projectile is in the air until it returns to the launch vertical level.
Highest vertical position reached relative to the launch point.
For level-ground range without air resistance, the angle that maximizes range is 45°.

topics.summary: Use derived closed-form formulas for time, height, and range when launch and landing heights are equal; adjust methods when initial and final heights differ.

topics.title: Problem-Solving Strategies and Advanced Considerations
key_concepts: When landing height differs from launch height, solve vertical motion equation y(t) = y0 + v0y t - (1/2) g t^2 for t (quadratic).
Trajectory equation eliminating t: y(x) = x tanθ - (g x^2) / (2 v0^2 cos^2 θ).
Common pitfalls: forgetting to decompose vectors, sign errors for g, mixing degrees and radians, and assuming symmetric motion when heights differ.

important_terms.definition: Case where initial height y0 ≠ 0; requires solving quadratic for time of flight and can yield two positive roots only in special geometry.
Equation giving vertical position as a function of horizontal position: y(x) = x tanθ - (g x^2) / (2 v0^2 cos^2 θ).
A non-conservative force that modifies projectile paths; usually neglected in introductory problems but causes non-parabolic trajectories.

topics.summary: Approach complex projectile problems by component decomposition, applying kinematics in each axis, solving quadratics when necessary, and checking limiting cases; note when air resistance or rotation must be considered.

questions.question_text: At what launch angle (above horizontal) is the range of a projectile on level ground maximized (neglecting air resistance)?
questions.explanation: Range R = (v0^2 sin 2θ)/g is maximized when sin 2θ = 1 → 2θ = 90° → θ = 45°.

questions.question_text: Explain, in one sentence, why horizontal and vertical motions are treated independently in projectile problems.
questions.correct_answer: Because gravity acts only vertically (in ideal problems) and there is no horizontal acceleration, so x and y motions follow separate kinematic equations.
questions.explanation: Independence follows from Newton's second law with no horizontal force: horizontal acceleration = 0, vertical acceleration = -g.

questions.question_text: A ball is launched horizontally from a 20 m high cliff with initial speed 15 m/s. How long does it take to hit the ground? (give numeric answer)
questions.explanation: Time from y: y = y0 - (1/2) g t^2 → t = sqrt(2 y0 / g) = sqrt(40 / 9.81) ≈ 2.02 s.

questions.question_text: A projectile is launched at 20.0 m/s at 40.0° above the horizontal. Find the time of flight (s).
Using the same launch (20.0 m/s, 40.0°), find the horizontal range (m).
For a launch speed 20.0 m/s at 40.0°, find the maximum height reached (m).
A projectile is launched horizontally from 45.0 m high with speed 10.0 m/s. Find the horizontal distance traveled before impact (m).
questions.explanation: Time t = sqrt(2 h / g) ≈ 3.03 s; horizontal distance = v_x * t = 10.0 * 3.03 ≈ 30.3 m.

questions.question_text: On level ground, which factor below does NOT change the angle that gives maximum range (45°) for an ideal projectile?
questions.explanation: In ideal projectile motion without air resistance, mass cancels out; air resistance changes the optimal angle, and g or speed do not change the angle of 45° in the ideal case.

questions.question_text: A projectile is launched from a height y0 = 10.0 m with speed 30.0 m/s at 30.0°. Compute the time until it hits the ground (s).
questions.explanation: Solve y(t)=y0+v0y t - 1/2 g t^2 = 0 with v0y = 30*sin30° = 15 m/s → 10 + 15 t - 4.905 t^2 = 0. Positive root t ≈ 3.62 s.

questions.question_text: Write the trajectory equation y(x) for a projectile launched from ground level with speed v0 at angle θ.
questions.correct_answer: y(x) = x tanθ - (g x^2) / (2 v0^2 cos^2 θ)
questions.explanation: Eliminate t: x = v0 cosθ t → t = x/(v0 cosθ); substitute into y = v0 sinθ t - (1/2) g t^2 to get given expression.

questions.question_text: Conceptual: If air resistance is significant, what qualitative effect does it have on range and symmetry of the trajectory?
questions.correct_answer: Air resistance reduces range and breaks symmetry: the descending path is steeper and range is shorter than ideal predictions.
questions.explanation: Drag removes kinetic energy and exerts a horizontal/vertical force, reducing horizontal distance and making ascent/descent times and shapes unequal.
